docs.title: FlowLab — Laboratory Workflow Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the FlowLab Laboratory Use Case Documentation, a technical writing portfolio project that models the lifecycle of laboratory exam processing — from patient registration to secure report delivery.

This documentation demonstrates how complex operational workflows can be translated into clear, structured technical communication.

docs.title: Project Purpose
docs.text:
This project simulates a real-world laboratory information system and focuses on:

  • translating operational workflows into readable documentation
  • structuring complex processes for clarity
  • defining actors, lifecycle states, and responsibilities
  • demonstrating technical writing best practices

All systems, data, and identifiers are fictional and exist solely for documentation purposes.

docs.title: System Overview
docs.text:
FlowLab represents a laboratory ecosystem where:

  • patient samples are registered and tracked
  • diagnostic devices generate exam results
  • interface software translates device output
  • technical staff validate sector-specific exams
  • lab management performs final approval
  • reports are securely generated and delivered
  • optional integration with external hospital systems occurs

The workflow models real operational constraints while remaining implementation-agnostic.

docs.title: Laboratory Analysis System — Use Case Overview
Purpose
docs.text: This document describes an operator-focused laboratory workflow managed by FlowLab, covering the full lifecycle from patient registration and sample handling to exam validation, report generation, and secure delivery. All entities and examples are fictional.

docs.title: Actors
docs.text:
• Reception staff — patient registration and sample collection
  • Triage staff — routes samples to the appropriate sectors and handles final disposal
  • Sector technical staff — exam verification and release
  • Lab manager — final approval and signature
  • Interface workstation — device listener and data translator
  • FlowLab server — processing, storage, workflow orchestration
  • External hospital system — clinical system integration
  • Patient — report recipient

docs.title: Interface
docs.text:
The Interface is workstation software directly connected to diagnostic devices. It continuously listens to device output, receives low-level machine messages, translates them into structured records, and inserts them into the FlowLab database (modeled as a MySQL-style environment).

This component bridges laboratory hardware and modern data systems.

docs.title: Patient ID and Sample Protocol
docs.text:
FlowLab separates patient identity from sample identity:

  • Patient ID — persistent identifier tied to the individual (public health number, military registry, insurance ID, etc.)
  • Sample Protocol — unique identifier for each laboratory visit

When a returning patient provides their ID, the system retrieves existing records automatically, accelerating registration. The protocol links the collected sample to the patient and drives all downstream processing.

docs.title: Status Lifecycle
docs.text:
Pending → Released → Signed → Report Generated
  • Pending — exam received from device
  • Released — validated by sector staff
  • Signed — approved by lab manager
  • Report Generated — consolidated PDF created

docs.title: Sector
docs.text: A functional laboratory group (Hematology, Biochemistry, Microbiology, etc.) responsible for validating specific exams.

docs.title: Preconditions
docs.text:
• Diagnostic devices are physically connected to dedicated interface workstations.
  • Workstations are connected to the internal network and communicate with the FlowLab server.
  • Interface software is configured for device communication and database submission.
  • Users have appropriate credentials and roles.

docs.title: Primary Workflow (Happy Path)
docs.text:
1. Reception registers the patient or retrieves existing data using Patient ID.
  2. A new sample protocol is created and linked to the patient record.
  3. The collected sample is sent to triage.
  4. Triage routes the sample to required diagnostic sectors.
  5. Devices perform exams within their sectors.
  6. Interface software captures device output and stores exam data as Pending.
  7. Sector staff review and validate results → status becomes Released.
  8. Once all required sectors complete validation, the lab manager signs results → Signed.
  9. FlowLab merges sector outputs into a unified PDF report.
  10. The report is published to the patient portal.
  11. Exam data is optionally transmitted via REST integration with an external Hospital Main Information System.
  12. After processing is complete, the sample returns to triage for disposal.

docs.title: Alternate Flows and Exceptions
docs.text:
• Device parsing failure — Interface flags data for manual review.
  • Out-of-range results — staff follow lab procedure rules: annotate, repeat tests, or correct entries.
  • Incomplete sector validation — manager approval is blocked until all required exams are released.

docs.title: Patient Record
docs.text:
• Patient ID
  • Name
  • Sample protocol
  • Collection timestamp
  • Personal data bundle (administrative and demographic information)

docs.title: Exam Record
docs.text:
• Device ID
  • Test code
  • Measurement values
  • Units and reference ranges
  • Validation comments
  • Timestamps

docs.title: Audit Trail
docs.text:
• User action history
  • Modification timestamps
  • Original device payload

docs.title: Non-Functional Considerations
docs.text:
• Secure transport (TLS)
  • Role-based access control
  • Reliable device-to-server communication
  • Retry queues for transmission failures
  • Full auditability and traceability

docs.title: Deployment Notes
docs.text:
• Interface workstations remain colocated with diagnostic devices.
  • Monitoring should track device connectivity, queue backlog, and processing errors.
  • Network reliability is critical to workflow continuity.

docs.title: Living Document Notice
docs.text: This overview represents a generalized laboratory workflow. Sector definitions, device types, and policies should be adapted to local operational standards.

docs.title: FlowLab Quickstart Guide
docs.text:
This quickstart provides a practical checklist to deploy FlowLab in a laboratory environment and validate the complete sample lifecycle — from patient registration to report delivery and external system integration.

The goal is to confirm that devices, Interface software, verification workflow, and report distribution operate correctly.

docs.title: 1 — Environment Requirements
docs.text:
Prepare the following components before deployment:

  • A server or VM for the FlowLab backend (API + database).
  • Network-connected workstations for each laboratory sector.
  • Diagnostic devices connected to workstations (serial or network).
  • Interface software package for device communication.
  • User accounts with appropriate roles:
  • Reception staff
  • Sector technical staff
  • Lab manager
  • Network access to the patient portal and optional hospital integration endpoint.

docs.title: 2 — Deploy the FlowLab Server
docs.text:
• Install the FlowLab backend on the central server.
  • Configure database connectivity (assume MySQL-compatible environment).
  • Enable TLS encryption for API communication.
  • Configure logging, monitoring, and database backup routines.
  • Verify API accessibility from laboratory workstations.

docs.title: 3 — Configure Interface Workstations
docs.text:
For each workstation connected to diagnostic devices:

  • Install Interface software.
  • Configure device parsers for each supported model.
  • Define FlowLab API endpoint and credentials.
  • Enable local retry queue and audit logging.
  • Validate device connectivity and parser output.

The Interface must successfully translate device messages into structured exam records.

docs.title: 4 — Register a Test Patient and Protocol
docs.text:
• At Reception, create a test patient record.
  • Assign or retrieve a patient identifier (existing or new).
  • Generate a protocol/sample ID.
  • Confirm patient data is linked to the protocol.

This validates patient identity mapping and sample tracking.

docs.title: 5 — Execute a Full Sample Workflow Test
docs.text:
Simulate or run a real test exam:

  1. Send the sample to triage.
  2. Route the sample to a diagnostic device sector.
  3. Allow the device to produce exam output.
  4. Confirm the Interface submits a record with status Pending.

Then validate workflow progression:

  • Sector technical staff review and mark result Released.
  • Lab manager signs the result (Signed).
  • FlowLab generates or merges the patient PDF report.
  • Confirm report availability in the patient portal.
  • Confirm REST transmission to the hospital system (if enabled).
  • Verify sample lifecycle closure at triage.

docs.title: 6 — Validate Status Lifecycle
docs.text:
Ensure the exam transitions correctly:

Pending → Released → Signed → Report Generated

Any deviation indicates workflow or permission misconfiguration.

docs.title: 7 — Troubleshooting Checklist
docs.text:
If issues occur:

No device data received

  • Verify serial/network connections.
  • Inspect Interface logs.
  • Confirm parser configuration.

Parsing or ingestion failures

  • Validate device output format.
  • Check Interface retry queue.
  • Review FlowLab ingestion logs.

Workflow block

  • Confirm user role permissions.
  • Ensure required sector validation is complete.

Report issues

  • Verify PDF generation logs.
  • Confirm portal connectivity.

docs.title: 8 — Integration Validation (Optional)
docs.text:
If hospital system integration is enabled:

  • Monitor REST payload transmission.
  • Confirm receipt in the hospital information system.
  • Validate patient record linkage.

docs.title: 9 — Recommended Practices
docs.text:
• Use synthetic test data — never real patient data.
  • Capture device payload samples for parser verification.
  • Monitor Interface queues for unexpected backlog.
  • Document configuration changes for traceability.

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text:
A successful quickstart confirms:

  • Device → Interface communication
  • Correct status lifecycle execution
  • Cross-sector validation workflow
  • PDF report generation and merge
  • Portal publication
  • Optional hospital system integration

This establishes a verified baseline deployment for FlowLab in a laboratory environment.

docs.title: FlowLab — Use Case: Complete Example
docs.text: This document is a portfolio-ready, end-to-end use case that shows how a laboratory exam flows from device capture to PDF report publication. It includes a synthetic device payload, API ingestion example, verification checks, a short audit query, and the recommended evidence to attach to a portfolio.

docs.title: Scenario
docs.text:
• Patient: John Silva
  • Patient ID: PT-000123
  • Protocol / Sample ID: PROT-20260214-0001
  • Collection timestamp: 2026-02-14T09:12:00Z

Goal: validate the happy-path workflow from device output ingestion through sector validation, manager approval, PDF generation, and portal delivery.

docs.title: 1) Example device payload (synthetic)
docs.text:
{
  "device_id": "DEV-HEM-001",
  "protocol": "PROT-20260214-0001",
  "patient_id": "PT-000123",
  "timestamp": "2026-02-14T09:13:21Z",
  "tests": [
    { "code": "HGB", "value": 13.6, "unit": "g/dL", "range": "12-16" },
    { "code": "WBC", "value": 6.2, "unit": "10^3/uL", "range": "4-11" }
  ]
}

docs.title: 2) Ingestion example (cURL)
docs.text:
Simulate the Interface posting an exam to the ingestion endpoint:

curl -X POST https://flowlab.internal/api/exams \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer <API_KEY>" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d @device-payload.json

Expected response (200 OK):

{
  "exam_id": "EXAM-20260214-0001",
  "status": "Pending"
}

docs.title: 3) Expected transitions and verification timeline
docs.text:
• 2026-02-14T09:13:21Z — Ingested: Pending (verify status in API response)
  • 2026-02-14T09:20:00Z — Sector staff validate → Released (check audit trail)
  • 2026-02-14T09:30:00Z — Manager approves → Signed
  • 2026-02-14T09:31:00Z — PDF generated → Report Generated and published to portal

Quick verification steps:

  • Confirm exam via GET /api/exams/{exam_id}
  • Inspect Interface logs for device_id and protocol
  • Verify report presence via GET /api/reports/{protocol}

Verification query example:

SELECT protocol, status, updated_at, changed_by
FROM exams
WHERE protocol = 'PROT-20260214-0001';

docs.title: 4) Summary
docs.text: "I simulated the end-to-end laboratory exam lifecycle: from device capture through ingestion, sector validation, manager approval, and PDF publication. I modeled the device payload, defined state transitions, and documented verification steps including API examples and audit queries. The artifact shows how operational lab processes can be converted into clear, testable documentation suitable for system integrators and operations teams."
